Award.AwardTitle: Metabolism of plant derived small RNAs in Spider Mites

Division.LongName: Div Of Molecular and Cellular Bioscience

Award.AbstractNarration:
Spider mites are the number one most pesticide resistant crop pest worldwide. It has relatively few predators and is difficult to control. Its genome sequence has been determined recently, and it is much smaller than in its arthropod relatives, but contains an enlarged collection of genes involved in RNA interference (RNAi), a pathway that uses RNA molecules to turn genes on and off. The project will study how these genes work when a mite ingests small RNA when feeding on plants, and whether this system can be used to control gene expression in the animal. The research activities associated with this project will provide training at the graduate and undergraduate level in biochemistry, genetics, and computational biology. It will rely heavily on the involvement of undergraduate researchers, both in the classroom and the laboratory.

The approach of the project involves exploring the ability of naturally occurring plant RNAs to accumulate in spider mites. After being raised on a variety of plants, the identity of plant RNAs entering mite cells will be determined with high throughput sequencing. Next, synthetic RNAs targeted to essential mite genes modeled from accumulating native plant molecules will be fed to mites and their effects on survival and gene expression investigated. RNAs that successfully modulate genes in mites will be characterized biochemically and in cell culture to understand the mechanism they exploit.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project investigated how a popular tool for genetics works in a group of animals that have not been well-studied: mites. These animals are fairly unrelated to the most well-studied ones, which led to the hypothesis that genetic mechanisms are going to work differently in mites. The tool that the project studied is called RNA interference (RNAi). The popularity of RNAi is partly due to ease of use. Compared to other methods the requirements are very basic which rely on reprogramming naturally occurring molecules. The result is a temporary decrease in the amount of product made by a gene targeted by the reprogrammed molecule. The animal’s DNA is not changed in the process, meaning the animal is not a genetically modified organism (GMO). A major application of RNAi that is gaining commercial traction is for pest control in agriculture. Technology based on RNAi has the potential to transform pesticide use. Unlike the small toxic molecules used in most pesticides, RNAi is very species specific, which means that only the pest could be killed, sparing all the beneficial organisms in the field. Unfortunately, how RNAi works is not consistent between different animals. Therefore there is great value in understanding how the mechanism works in animals unrelated to the well-studied species. The focus of this project is the two-spotted spider mite. It is the most economically impactful mite species that infests hundreds of crops and ornamental plants. It is also able to rapidly develop pesticide resistance, making spider mites a prime candidate for RNAi.

To understand RNAi mechanisms in mites we examined two different species, spider mites and dust mites. This comparison highlighted the dramatic differences in the way RNAi works between different types of mites. Generally, there are three types of RNAi recognized in animals. The first is the microRNA (miRNA) pathway which works the same in all animals. It is part of normal cell function. The second is the small-interfering RNA (siRNA), which insects use to fight viruses. The last is the piwi-associated RNA (piRNA). piRNAs have a role in surveillance of an animal’s DNA. There are many parts of an animal’s DNA that are parasite-like and if they are not controlled will begin to replicate and damage the DNA. In humans and insects piRNAs are involved in controlling the DNA parasites. When we looked at how the three types of RNAi work in the two mites we found prevailing views about their roles to not apply in these organisms. The situation in dust mites was particularly unusual as they had completely lost piRNAs. The dust mite piRNAs were replaced by a variety of siRNAs. In spider mites we observed a similar arrangement where there was some replacement of piRNAs by siRNAs but it was less drastic. We could still see spider mite piRNAs but they are secondary to the siRNAs. These insights were valuable for the next stage of the project that looked into the type of RNAi that would make the most effective tool in spider mites.

If RNAi is going to an effective pesticide then the reprogrammed molecules that trigger it will likely need to be ingested by the pest. As the RNAi mechanism varies by animal it is important to identify the most potent trigger configuration for that species. For insects, most strategies involve getting the animal to make siRNAs. We tested this same strategy alongside others in spider mites and found that miRNA-like triggers were more effective. This result has broad implications for using RNAi for pest control, specifically that current approaches could be improved by using different types of triggers. During these experiments we also characterized the metabolism of plant material by RNAi, which corroborated that miRNA-type RNAi is more efficient in these animals.

In addition to the scientific goals of the project, there was significant benefit to the training environment at the University of Southern Mississippi (USM). The project supported two graduate students, one of which has graduated with a PhD based solely on project results. The project also supported two undergraduate honor’s research theses. Research efforts also impacted classrooms at USM. Animals raised during the study were incorporated into teaching labs. In one of the articles published during the course of the project a class produced results that led to acknowledgement for the class. 

In total the project produced four papers, one of which is under review. There were four posters presented at international meetings, and three talks at universities or conferences.
